Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms for sensory prediction in a cerebellum-like circuit
Award.AbstractNarration: Complex nervous systems endow animals with the ability to predict, rather than merely react to, external events. Predictions allow past experience to guide action and are critical for both perception and movement. The goal of this research project is to understand the mechanisms that underlie predictive capacities at the levels of synapses, neurons, and circuits. The research takes advantage of a model system that is uniquely suited to address these issues. Electric fish generate weak electrical fields and, by sensing changes in these fields, are able to navigate and find prey in the dark. However to properly interpret these electrosensory signals, the fish must learn to predict and cancel out components of the input that are a direct result of the fish's own movement. The problem of differentiating self-generated from external sensory signals is a very general one, faced by all animals, including humans. A number of unique advantages have enabled major progress in understanding the neurobiological mechanisms for prediction and cancellation in the brains of electric fish. Interestingly, the neural circuitry for generating predictions in electric fish is highly similar to that of the mammalian cerebellum. Though known to be important for coordinated movement, the exact function of the cerebellum is not understood. Recently, several lines of evidence have suggested that the primate cerebellum may function to predict sensory events, similar to the known function of cerebellum-like circuits in fish. This project will yield novel insights into the functions of cerebellar circuitry and the neural mechanisms for predicting sensory events. Educational outreach will take advantage of the intriguing sensory and motor capacities of electric fish to provide students and teachers with an exciting entry point into biology and physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our seamless perception of the external world is an active creation of our nervous system. Direct perception of images projected onto our eyes would be of little use. For example it would appear that the entire world moved rapidly several times every second. This is because we move our eyes several times each second in oder to direct our fovea (the region of the eye with the greatest resolving power) to objects of interest. A fundamental step in perception, therefore, is the removal of sensory inputs that are a direct consequence of an animal's own behavior.  Failures of this process have been implicated in neurological disorders such as schizophrenia, in which patients confuse their own thoughts with voices originating outside of themselves.

The goal of our NSF funded research was to understand the neural mechanisms that underlie this process of predicting and  filtering out self-generated inputs.  Detailed studies of neural circuits in humans are difficult or impossible, hence we turned to a different model system--an electric fish from Africa that emits and senses weak electrical fields. These animals are ideal for our studies because circuits in their brains have been identified in which it is possible to directly observe neural activity while the animal learns to predict and filter out electrical fields that the fish generates itself using specialized muscles in the tail.

By combining recordings from hundreds of neurons with mathematical modeling we developed a relatively complete description of the neural circuits that allow electric fish to distinguish self-generated versus external electrical fields.  We found that we could explain this process based on two key ingredients. The first is a mechanism to change the strength of neural connections. Interestingly, such synaptic plasticity, is also believed to underlie learning and memory in humans. The second is the ability to form an internal representation of elapsed time after a motor command is sent to the muscles.  Interestingly, we found that this representation is formed in cerebellar granule cells. These cells are the most numerous in the vertebrate brain, including the human brain, but until now very little has been known about their function.

Together, our results provide a concrete, mechanistic account of how the brain distinguishes self from other, a fundamental step in sensory perception.
